meanings.definition: To make a general statement or form a general opinion without considering all the facts.
meanings.sent1: She was generalising about cats being lazy based on just one cat she met.
meanings.sent2: Stop generalising about people's behavior without knowing their full story.
meanings.sent3: He kept generalising about the weather, predicting rain every time he saw a cloud.
meanings.sent4: Her tendency to generalise made her miss out on the unique qualities of each individual.
meanings.sent5: By generalising too quickly, you might overlook important details.

meanings.definition: To infer or assert something about a whole group based on a few individuals.
meanings.sent1: Generalising from a single example can lead to inaccurate conclusions.
meanings.sent2: Don't generalize about all dogs being friendly just because you met one nice dog.
meanings.sent3: He was generalising wildly, claiming all students were lazy based on a few he knew.
meanings.sent4: She was generalising like a detective, piecing together a theory from small clues.
meanings.sent5: By generalising too broadly, you risk overlooking the diversity within the group.

meanings.definition: To draw a broad conclusion from specific instances.
meanings.sent1: Generalising from limited data can lead to misleading results.
meanings.sent2: Avoid generalising about people's preferences based on just a few examples.
meanings.sent3: He was generalising humorously, claiming all birds were afraid of heights.
meanings.sent4: She was generalising in a way that simplified complex situations.
meanings.sent5: By generalising too hastily, you might miss the nuances of each case.
